Title:
Charactreization of fungi causing a lesion blight on papaver
dubium in Iran
Keywords: Ascochyta, Blight disease, Phoma, Phylogeny, Weed
Abstract:
Papaver dubium (common name blindeyes, Papaveraceae) is
widespread throughout Europe and America and is an important weed in
western Iran. Since 2009, a blight disease causing significant damage to
plants of P. dubium in several areas in Hamedan province, Iran has
occurred. The disease caused initially small, yellowbrown lesions on
lower leaves, and eventually expanded to the whole plant resulting in
necrotic lesions and complete wilting. This study was carried out to
identify the causal agent(s) of the blight disease on blindeyes. On the
basis of cultural and microscopic characters, plus phylogenetic analysis
of 5.8S nrDNA (ITS), partial β-tubulin (TUB2), and partial LSU rDNA, 82
isolates were identified as follows: Ascochyta chelidoniicola (42),
Neodidymelliopsis sp. (28), Allophoma zantedeschiae (12). Pathogenicity
tests in the greenhouse showed that all isolates of A. chelidoniicola
and Neodidymelliopsis sp. caused typical spots on inoculated plants, and
were successfully reisolated from the symptomatic tissues. Our results
clearly indicated that A. chelidoniicola was the major pathogen causing
the lesion blight disease on blindeyes in western Iran on the basis of
high isolation frequency and continuous occurance from 2009 to 2015. To
the best of our knowledge, all three species in this study are new taxa
for mycobiota of Iran.
